author: By Nicole Hong and Jeenah Moon
title: Times Square at Its Overcrowded, Dizzying Worst Is Exactly What N.Y.C. Needs
description: The economic future of New York depends on everyone coming back, not just the tourists. Too bad office workers don’t want to join them.
content: The sensory-overloaded tower will offer visitors the chance to do quite a lot, all in one place: They will be able to sing along with a hologram of their favorite pop star, spend their cryptocurrency, marvel at ever-changing digital art on the walls and dine on a 10,000-square-foot outdoor terrace. It will be an enviable perch to gaze out at Times Square, a neighborhood that before the pandemic represented 15 percent of the city’s economic output in just 0.1 percent of the land area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Roommate Won’t Pay Rent and Won’t Leave. What Can I Do?
description: When housing courts become involved, there’s often little to do but wait. However, a private settlement is often the best way forward.
content: Q: Two years ago, my wife and I got a roommate to share the rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan that we’ve lived in for 40 years. A year ago, he stopped paying rent for his room — he didn’t claim job loss or another hardship, he just refused to pay. We do not have a written agreement with him, so we asked him to move out, but he refused. We hired a lawyer, but our claim could not proceed because he applied for the Emergency Rental Assistance Program, and that case is still pending. He has tried to verbally intimidate me, and has periodically locked me out of my apartment. The police have come a few times but have taken no action. What can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Medvedev Seizes Chance to Make an Impression on French Open Fans
description: Daniil Medvedev and other Russians, barred from competing at Wimbledon because of the war in Ukraine, have made a run in the French Open. The ban remains a sensitive issue in tennis.
content: PARIS — Banned from Wimbledon, the Russians seem intent on making the most of the Grand Slam tournament at hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: A Monumental Centennial
description: Daniel Bodily and Jeff Chen score with a historical Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This grid makes such a wonderful visual impact, doesn’t it? Daniel Bodily, of Woodbury, Minn., is an R. & D. robotics engineer who started making puzzles three years ago. “Every once in a while I pick a ‘mammoth goal’ — something way out of my comfort zone,” says Dan, and in 2019 that goal was to have a puzzle published in The Times. Jeff Chen of Seattle is a professional writer and puzzle constructor, who has collaborated with 49 people, so far, on Times puzzles (per his own invaluable puzzle data site, xwordinfo.com). Today’s puzzle is this duo’s second construction together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: When the Cost of Liberty Is the Occasional Massacre
description: Conservatives need to explain their logic on gun safety.
content: The gun was legal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Gen Z Is Cynical. They’ve Earned It.
description: Without much confidence that the olds will have fixes on guns, climate or Covid, young Americans are looking to themselves.
content: Cameron Kasky had just gotten off the phone with his grandfather when I talked to him on Wednesday, the day after the massacre at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, that left 19 children and two teachers dead. Kasky, who is 21, was a student at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., when 17 people were killed there in 2018 by a teenager with an AR-15 rifle. Kasky said his Pop Pop “was giving me the post-mass-shooting-how-you-doing call,” which, we both noted, happens with pathetic, maddening, horrifying regularity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: The Texas Law That Has Banks Saying They Don’t ‘Discriminate’ Against Guns
description: Recent legislation requires firms to declare that they don’t “discriminate” against the firearm industry — or risk losing lucrative business with the state.
content: Four years ago, JPMorgan Chase joined some of the nation’s largest banks in publicly distancing itself from the firearm industry after a mass shooting in Parkland, Fla., left 17 people dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: The Gunman in Uvalde Left Multiple Hints Before His Attack Began
description: Particularly online, the teenager who killed 19 students and two teachers at an elementary school provided dark warnings about the carnage to come.
content: UVALDE, Texas — It did not go without notice when an 18-year-old who frequently sparred with classmates before dropping out of high school posted a picture of two long, black rifles on his Instagram story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: Dinosaurs Started Out Hot, Then Some of Them Turned Cold
description: Scientists directly measured the metabolic rate of extinct animals, which revealed that some giant dinosaurs became coldblooded.
content: Paleontologists have long wrangled with the question of dinosaur metabolisms — whether they ran hot, like modern birds and mammals do, or resembled the slower metabolisms of modern reptiles. In a surprise, the answer seems to be both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: What Canada Doesn’t Know About Its Guns
description: New record-keeping requirements for nonrestricted firearms began this month, but the origins of Canada’s so-called crime guns are largely unknown.
content: A drone lifted off from Michigan this month and flew across the St. Clair River toward Port Lambton, Ontario. Its spooked pilot aborted the landing after being spotted by a neighbor, leaving the police to later fish the drone out of a tree and discover 11 handguns strapped to it with plastic bags, tape and carabiner clips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: America’s Human Sacrifices
description: Guns don’t kill people. Doors do.
content: WASHINGTON — Once, when I thought of child sacrifice, I thought of ancient shibboleths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: How a Mapmaker Became New York’s Most Unexpected Power Broker
description: Jonathan Cervas, a former bartender from Las Vegas, radically redrew New York’s House district lines, forcing some Democratic incumbents to scramble for new seats.
content: He is a postdoctoral fellow from Pittsburgh, a bartender turned political mapmaker. Now, Jonathan Cervas is suddenly New York’s most unforeseen power broker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Heartbroken Nation
description: America’s leaders are failing in their most basic duty.
content: The United States seems to be failing to protect its people by the week. With the gun massacre in East Buffalo followed by the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, many Americans have spent the past few days gripped by overwhelming incredulity and grief, exhaustion and fury over the loss of life. What can be done beyond living with heartbreak?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: U.S. Forest Service Planned Burn Caused Largest New Mexico Wildfire
description: The Calf Canyon and Hermits Peak fires, which merged, started as prescribed burns intended to prevent wildfires, federal officials said.
content: A wildfire in northern New Mexico that destroyed at least 330 homes and displaced thousands of people was caused by a planned burn by the U.S. Forest Service, federal fire investigators said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yegor Firsov
title: I Thought I Could Get Away From War. Now I’m a Medic on the Front Line.
description: In my experience, people want to fill death-ravaged space with as much life as possible.
content: I’m from a small town called Avdiivka, in eastern Ukraine. Avdiivka has been a front line for eight years, but its name has not yet made it to the front pages of world newspapers. Thank goodness for that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Prosecutors and Defense Duel in Closing Arguments of Politically Charged Trial
description: A verdict is expected as early as Tuesday in the case brought by a Trump-era special counsel against a lawyer with ties to Hillary Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign.
content: WASHINGTON — Prosecutors and a defense lawyer put forward starkly opposing views on Friday in closing arguments for the politically charged trial of Michael Sussmann, a cybersecurity lawyer with ties to Hillary Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Drones. Crutches. Potatoes. Russians Crowdfund Their Army.
description: A grass-roots movement to get basic supplies to soldiers fighting in Ukraine reflects the growing recognition among Russians that their military was unprepared for major conflict.
content: Natalia Abiyeva is a real-estate agent specializing in rental apartments in the city of Nizhny Novgorod, east of Moscow. But lately, she has been learning a lot about battlefield medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: What the Racist Massacre in Buffalo Stole From One Family
description: Every mass shooting requires unique paths of mourning. Celestine Chaney’s family bid farewell to a mother, sister, grandparent and best friend.
content: BUFFALO — He stood next to his mother as she lay in her white coffin, gliding his palm between his 9-year-old son’s back and his grown daughter’s shoulder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Schwartz
title: Australia Wields a New DNA Tool to Crack Missing-Person Mysteries
description: The technique can predict a person’s ancestry and physical traits without the need for a match with an existing sample in a database.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — When a man washed up on the shores of Christmas Island in 1942, lifeless and hunched over in a shrapnel-riddled raft, no one knew who he was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: An Irish National Treasure Gets Set for a Long-Needed Restoration
description: The majestic Old Library at Trinity College Dublin, where some of Ireland’s most ancient and valuable books are stored, is a popular tourist attraction.
content: DUBLIN — The Long Room, with its imposing oak ceiling and two levels of bookshelves laden with some of Ireland’s most ancient and valuable volumes, is the oldest part of the library in Trinity College Dublin, in constant use since 1732.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of May 23, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eden Weingart
title: How Do You Find an Apartment in N.Y.C. These Days?
description: Apartment hunting in the city has never been easy, but now the search has become seemingly impossible as prices soar. Readers told us about their pandemic housing struggles — and eventual successes.
content: It’s not an easy time to find an apartment to rent in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Debate Over Guns Unfolds in Uvalde, a Rural Texas Town in Grief
description: Guns are a central part of life in Uvalde, yet the deaths of 19 children and two teachers have opened rifts.
content: UVALDE, Texas — Living in a rural Texas town renowned for white-tailed deer hunting, where rifles are a regular prize at school raffles, Desirae Garza never thought much about gun laws. That changed after her 10-year-old niece, Amerie Jo, was fatally shot inside Robb Elementary School.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: One Nation, Under Guns
description: Will we rise up to face the rising tide of violence?
content: Gail Collins: Bret, did you hear that what the city billed as “the final New York City public pay telephone” was just whisked away?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Tarnoff
title: The Internet Is Broken. How Do We Fix It?
description: The online system is broken. How do we fix it?
content: At the bottom of the ocean there is a garden hose stuffed with glass. Life is difficult at this depth. Plants are unknown; oxygen is scarce. There are eels with very large mouths and fish that glow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: Gun in Texas Shooting Came From Company Known for Pushing Boundaries
description: Daniel Defense, which makes military-style rifles, was an early adopter of direct-to-consumer marketing and has a history of running provocative ads.
content: After one of its military-style rifles was used in the Texas elementary school shooting on Tuesday, the gun manufacturer Daniel Defense published a pop-up statement on its home page sending “thoughts and prayers” to the community of Uvalde, Texas, and pledging to cooperate with the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Testing Positive and Using the ‘Backdoor’ to Get Into the U.S.
description: Entering the United States by air requires a negative coronavirus test. Some people who can’t provide one are using a workaround: flying to Canada or Mexico, then entering via a land border.
content: Michelle Fishman calls it the “worst-case scenario that you don’t really think through.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Katherine Clemmons
title: Her Race Against A.L.S.: 50 Marathons in 50 States
description: Andrea Peet surpassed the average A.L.S. life expectancy in 2019. So she decided to race a new kind of clock: 50 marathons in 50 states.
content: Andrea Peet had just passed the 11th mile of the 2020 Mississippi Blues Marathon when she felt an abrupt jolt. She’d already steered around several potholes on the course, but she had seen this one too late. Her recumbent trike veered off course. As she steadied the wheels, she realized she had a bigger problem: She couldn’t pedal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Diplomats Fear Russia May Use Syrian Aid as Bargaining Chip in Ukraine
description: Countries in Europe and the Middle East could see a new surge in refugees if Russia shuts down the last humanitarian convoy route into Syria.
content: WASHINGTON — Only one route remains open for international convoys bringing food, water and other aid to over one million Syrians besieged by civil war. Now, officials warn, Russia might try to shut it down or use it as a bargaining chip with world powers in another war, about 1,000 miles away in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Abbott has occasionally talked about tightening Texas gun laws.
description: After mass shootings in 2018, Gov. Greg Abbott indicated an openness to tightening the state’s gun laws, but they remain some of the least restrictive in the country.
content: In the seven years that Greg Abbott has served as governor of Texas, dozens of people have been killed in mass shootings across the state. In a few cases, his administration has responded to the violence by indicating an openness to tightening the state’s gun laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Ukrainian Orthodox Church Breaks With Moscow Over War
description: The Council of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church said that it disagreed with the Moscow Patriarch’s position on the war.
content: The leaders of the central branch of the Orthodox church in Ukraine have made a formal break with the hierarchy in Moscow, widening the schism in a church that was already divided before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter and Ryan Christopher Jones
title: Illegal Immigration Is Down, Changing the Face of California Farms
description: Farmers are turning to workers on seasonal visas and mechanizing what they can. Many labor-intensive crops are shifting south of the border.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Tropical Storm Agatha Headed to the Mexican Coast
description: This year’s first named storm in the eastern Pacific has the potential to become a Category 2 hurricane, forecasters said on Saturday.
content: Tropical Storm Agatha, the first named storm this year in the eastern Pacific, is hurtling toward the Mexican coast and has the potential to become a hurricane, triggering life-threatening flash floods and mudslides, the National Hurricane Center said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: ‘Yeah, That Happened.’ A Giants Player Is Slapped Over Fantasy Football.
description: Joc Pederson of the San Francisco Giants was slapped by Reds outfielder Tommy Pham. M.L.B. suspended Pham for three games.
content: When fights occur in professional sports it can sometimes take years for the facts to come out. Rumors will swirl, tidbits will be attributed to anonymous sources and years later the people involved will finally explain what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Americans Eye Housing Market, and Stay Put
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 28, 2022.
content: “What are you going to weigh more? A bigger yard, or a higher interest rate? The lack of storage, or the soaring price of housing? What’s finally going to be the tipping point?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Cardinal Angelo Sodano, Vatican Power Broker, Dies at 94
description: He rose to the second-highest-ranking position in the Roman Catholic Church, but his reputation was stained by his handling of sex-abuse cases.
content: ROME — Cardinal Angelo Sodano, who rose to the pinnacle of the Roman Catholic Church as the Vatican’s top diplomat, the ultimate power broker of the papal court and the deeply influential dean of cardinals before seeing his reputation stained by his connection with the cover-up of sex abuse scandals, died on Friday. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Trump and Cruz at the N.R.A. Convention
description: The former president and the Texas senator made inaccurate or misleading claims about the efficacy of gun restrictions, gun ownership trends and school shootings.
content: Prominent Republicans defended gun rights at the National Rifle Association convention on Friday with some misleading claims about the efficacy of gun restrictions, gun ownership trends and school shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Massacres Test Whether Washington Can Move Beyond Paralysis
description: The United States is facing a widening gap between the scale of gun violence and what America’s political leaders can agree are the right responses to the carnage.
content: WASHINGTON — Days after 19 children and two teachers were gunned down in Texas, politicians in Washington are tinkering around the edges of America’s gun laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Amid Gun Violence, Giants Manager Will Not Come Out for Anthem
description: San Francisco’s Gabe Kapler says he will not take the field during the national anthem “until I feel better about the direction of our country.”
content: Gabe Kapler observed his own moment of silence sometime before the San Francisco Giants team he manages opened its Memorial Day Weekend series in Cincinnati on Friday night. His moment came not before a national anthem nor while standing at attention at the edge of a dugout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Good News in Georgia That’s Bad News for Trump
description: Republicans in key swing-state offices can know that they have a future in the party if, in the event of a contested election, they simply do their job.
content: This is a column about good news, written in the shadow of the worst news imaginable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: U.N. Human Rights Chief Tempers Criticism at End of China Trip
description: Rights groups and overseas Uyghurs had called for vociferous condemnation of China’s policies toward minorities in the country’s far West. They were highly disappointed.
content: HONG KONG — The United Nations’ top human rights official offered limited criticism of China’s crackdown on predominately Muslim minorities, saying at the end of her six-day trip to the country on Saturday that she had raised questions about its application of “counterterrorism and de-radicalization measures” but that her visit “was not an investigation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Sounds of bombardment drown out the ‘last bell’ for the final day of school in Ukraine.
description: On what is usually a day of festivities and fun, many of Ukraine’s students ended the academic year amid the sounds of war or from abroad.
content: The final day of classes in Ukraine is normally a festive occasion when gleeful students get dressed up and jump into fountains — and as tradition dictates, the smallest student climbs onto the shoulders of the tallest to ring a bell marking the school year’s end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Triangle of Sadness’ wins Palme d’Or at Cannes.
description: The film festival’s top prize went to a brutal sendup of class politics directed by Ruben Ostlund, who also won in 2017 for his satire “The Square.”
content: CANNES, France — The satire “Triangle of Sadness,” from the Swedish director Ruben Ostlund, won the Palme d’Or at the 75th Cannes Film Festival at a ceremony here on Saturday. A blunt, ugly sendup of class politics, the movie had sharply divided critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: The N.R.A. Gathering in Houston Spotlights an American Divide
description: Gun supporters and protesters mourned two shooting massacres in a single month, but the gap in their views on what to do next remained wide.
content: HOUSTON — On one side of an avenue in downtown Houston, people filed into the National Rifle Association’s annual convention this weekend to talk guns, admire guns, buy guns and invoke as holy script the Second Amendment right to bear arms; that is, guns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: Summer Camp for All
description: It’s hard to imagine a more ideal escape for young people living through an extraordinary time of grief, loneliness and upheaval.
content: For some lucky American children, summer means campfires with new friends, long hikes in the woods, hot days swimming in cool lakes, magical nights under starry skies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: The Fall of the ‘Sun King’ of French TV, and the Myth of Seduction
description: Patrick Poivre d’Arvor, known as a great seducer, has been accused by more than 20 women of rape, sexual assault and harassment in France’s belated #MeToo reckoning.
content: PARIS — France’s most trusted anchorman for decades, he used to draw millions in an evening news program that some likened to a religious communion. In an earlier time, he embodied an ideal of the French male — at ease with himself, a TV journalist and man of letters, a husband and a father who was also, unabashedly, a great seducer of women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard, Corey Kilgannon, Jazmine Hughes, Emma Goldberg and Stephanie Mei-Ling
title: It’s Going to Be a Hot Summer. It Will Be Hotter if You’re Not Rich.
description: When heat waves hit, everyone suffers. But the pain will not be shared equally throughout New York City. Here, the neighborhoods where climate inequality will hurt the most.
content: As summer begins, danger lurks behind New Yorkers’ joy at getting back to beaches and parks. Blazing heat is expected to blanket most of the country, setting records as it has for several years running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Summer Reading
description: Today we look at this summer’s crop of new books.
content: It’s Memorial Day weekend, the unofficial start to summer, and the official start to summer reading. I’m smitten with the promise of a season spent buried in books, with “the possibility of long sunlit days spent unmoored from everyday restraints and immersed in a literary world,” as Jennifer Harlan wrote in The Times last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Activist Investing Has Come for Fossil Fuels. What About Guns?
description: With politicians unwilling to act, some investors are trying to use shareholder resolutions to get gun makers to rein in their products.
content: The message after a mass shooting, this time at a Texas elementary school, was clear: People who want to curb gun violence should “cast their vote in November.” That was how Senator Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader and Democrat of New York, put it on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Oh, You Thought the Miami Heat Were Done? Jimmy Butler Said No.
description: The Boston Celtics were one win away from the N.B.A. finals. After Butler’s 47-point Game 6 performance, the Miami Heat are, too.
content: BOSTON — In a playoff series that had long ago lost any semblance of order or predictability, Jimmy Butler of the Miami Heat on Friday night emerged as a rare source of stability, and perhaps the only one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: The Women of Fleet Week Hit the Town
description: Shore leave for 3,000 sailors in New York City no longer means a night out for the boys.
content: It takes a certain panache to wear white in New York City. And Khrzielle Vargas, a 21-year-old seaman apprentice from Fremont, Calif., was strolling through Times Square on Thursday afternoon in her white trousers, white jumper top and white sailor hat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: At N.R.A. Convention, the Blame Is on ‘Evil,’ Not Guns
description: Above all else, activists and politicians at the gathering sought to divert pressure to support popular overhauls like expanded background checks by seizing on the issue of school safety.
content: HOUSTON — One by one, the gun rights activists and politicians who showed up at the National Rifle Association convention on Friday said they were appalled, horrified and shaken by the massacre of 19 children and two adults a few days earlier in Uvalde, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli and Jonathan Abrams
title: Brittney Griner’s Supporters Have a New Strategy to Free Her: Make Noise
description: Those close to Griner pursued a strategy of silence after her detention in Russia in February, hoping to avoid politicizing her case. Now they are amping up public pressure, with some of it aimed at President Biden.
content: Her face is on hoodies. Her name is in hashtags. Her “B.G.” and number are on fans’ jerseys and W.N.B.A. courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes and Jeenah Moon
title: How a 7,000-Ton Broadway Theater Was Hoisted 30 Feet
description: The Beaux-Arts interior of the Palace Theater is a protected landmark, so developers had to devise a plan to raise it three stories in their effort to add more retail space.
content: If you’ve ever lost at Jenga by toppling a tower after removing a block, you might appreciate what developers have accomplished at TSX Broadway, a hotel and entertainment complex in Times Square.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Primary Losses Puncture His Invincibility
description: With many of Donald J. Trump’s endorsed candidates falling to defeat in recent primaries, some Republicans see an opening for a post-Trump candidate in 2024.
content: Donald J. Trump had cast this year’s primaries as a moment to measure his power, endorsing candidates by the dozen as he sought to maintain an imprint on his party unlike any other past president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Want a Nutcracker or a ‘Craft Cocktail?’ He’s Your Guy.
description: As the warm weather draws picnickers to Prospect Park, they can be sure to find the one and only Prince Lewis selling cold mixed drinks.
content: This story is part of an occasional series exploring nightlife (and daylife) in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Woman Gets 15 Months in Prison for Punching Flight Attendant in the Face
description: Prosecutors said Vyvianna M. Quinonez, 29, of Sacramento, will also have to pay nearly $26,000 in restitution and a $7,500 fine for the May 2021 attack, which was widely viewed online.
content: A California woman who repeatedly punched a Southwest Airlines flight attendant last year, bloodying her face and chipping three of her teeth, was sentenced on Friday to 15 months in federal prison, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: UEFA Blames Delay at Champions League Final on ‘Fake Tickets’
description: European soccer’s showcase game kicked off more than 30 minutes late after overcrowding at the stadium gates led to clashes between fans and the police.
content: PARIS — A logjam of fans that led to a 35-minute delay of the start of Saturday’s Champions League final between Real Madrid and Liverpool was caused by people attempting to use “fake tickets” to enter the match, the tournament’s organizer said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Ted Sarandos Talks About That Stock Drop, Backing Dave Chappelle, and Hollywood Schadenfreude
description: The Netflix executive says he — and the company he helped build — will survive a bout of bad earnings numbers.
content: Maybe it was the tower of seafood sitting before us. Or the Potomac River flowing next to us. Or the fact that Ted Sarandos proposed to his wife, Nicole, on a “touristy booze cruise” under Fourth of July fireworks right in front of where we were sitting on the Georgetown waterfront in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: In Los Angeles, a Tree With Stories to Tell
description: At the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, each champion received a baby oak tree. In Los Angeles one of them is still alive, a witness to a forgotten chapter of Black history. But it is threatened with destruction to make space for luxury apartments.
content: LOS ANGELES — In 1920s Los Angeles, a young boy refined his talents in the backyard of his family’s modest bungalow — running and jumping, running and jumping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: What Gun Violence Does to Our Mental Health
description: Mass shootings and other types of trauma can have ripple effects not only for survivors but also for those who follow the news of the events.
content: Heather Martin was a senior at Columbine High School in 1999 when two gunmen, also teenagers, killed 13 people and wounded 21 more before taking their own lives. She ended up barricaded in a room for three hours. And although she wasn’t physically injured, she witnessed the aftermath of the shooting, which she described as “horrifying.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Stampede at Church Fair in Nigeria Kills 31
description: Dozens of people arrived early to the fair, a charity event, and managed to break open a locked gate.
content: ABUJA, Nigeria — A stampede Saturday at a church charity event in southern Nigeria left 31 people dead and seven injured, the police told The Associated Press, a shocking development at a program that organizers said aimed to “offer hope” to the needy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Activities for Dummies
description: Joseph Greenbaum tests our mettle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I like the world Joseph Greenbaum creates with this puzzle, his fifth since last August; the pants are soft and the bow ties are starchy. There are lots of potential pitfalls and 10 debuts, but if you don’t get too attached to every assumption you make, this is a pretty good-natured grid. Take a minute and appreciate the interplay between the three stacked span entries in the middle, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Turner, Benjamin Lowy, Axel Boada and Nailah Morgan
title: ‘We’re Mad, Angry, Sad’: Uvalde Mourns School Shooting Victims
description: Grieving families and other residents visited memorials for the 21 victims killed by a gunman at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas.
content: Grieving families and other residents visited memorials for the 21 victims killed by a gunman at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas.

title: Corrections: May 28, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 28, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about Léolia Jeanjean and Fernanda Contreras Gomez’s path to their first Grand Slam tournament at the French Open misstated the year that Gómez met Christo van Rensburg as he was coaching players in Austin. It was in 2020, not 2001.
source.name: The New York Times
